awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: An Intelligent Re-Design Recommender System for Additive and Hybrid Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a potentially novel, robust, intelligent, and automated assessment and re-design global evaluation system that provides precise feedback on components’ printability for advanced manufacturing. Such evaluations could reduce mistakes and printing failures, potentially avoid costly trial-and-error exercises, and remove biases and inconsistencies that arise from inefficient or manual evaluation processes. This system allows for potentially effectively organizing assessments and can avoid costly computations and modifications. This capability, therefore, could prevent the waste of energy, time, and financial resources imposed by current manual assessments of components’ printability. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a novel re-design recommender system that may allow companies with large inventories of existing parts to quickly assess the feasibility of employing additive manufacturing for each part and to implement necessary re-design approaches as appropriate. The technology encompasses multiple intelligent assessments and re-design methodologies, as well as a fully automated correction system that rectifies the geometries of problematic components and converts designs to be advanced manufacturing compatible. These re-design solutions can potentially provide successful geometries for 3D-printing components using different techniques. Lastly, this technology can present a novel design recommender system that intelligently analyzes an extensive database of closely related components for advanced manufacturing using machine learning techniques to provide effective design recommendations for those component clusters whose current designs are deemed inefficient for advanced manufacturing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
This project is dedicated to the exploration of the potential for commercializing our advanced software technology tailored for Additive Manufacturing (AM) or 3D printing. Our technology pioneers the provision of a groundbreaking digital revolution in AM assessments and services, effectively resolving substantial hurdles within the AM industry. The project's achievements have been noteworthy, evidenced by completing over 180 comprehensive and insightful interviews throughout our customer discovery journey. Our understanding of a viable business model, testable value propositions, and the most suitable customer segments have matured effectively over the course of the project. Building on this foundation through an extensive iterative process and engaging in numerous interviews with industry professionals across various sectors of additive manufacturing, we have successfully refined our initial hypotheses. As a result, we have validated the core value propositions of our technology and formulated a well-defined version of our business model canvas. This process has significantly influenced our startup's vision, ultimately leading us to pinpoint two aerospace sectors as our most promising customer targets. Furthermore, it has enabled us to validate some of our hypotheses and clarify the benefits that our technology can provide to them such as increased revenue, reduced engineer workload, improved production capacity, and streamlined efficiency in managing part inventories.  

The project helped the team establish meaningful connections with potential customers, partners, investors, and industry experts, made possible by attending conferences and symposiums. These connections offer promising opportunities for future partnerships and collaborations. The project not only illuminated the commercial potential of our technology but also equipped us with a comprehensive skill set such as effective communication and shaping an entrepreneurial mindset. This process, based on reliable strategies from the market, has propelled our idea toward being ready for the market. Within the scope of the I-Corps project, our team successfully developed a website that effectively presents the benefits and applications of our technology to potential customers. Our website has the potential to become the central hub for our upcoming startup.

Ultimately, after our journey of exploration, the strong demand we identified across various sections of the AM industry during our customer discovery, coupled with positive feedback, has significantly boosted our team's excitement and determination to seriously pursue our entrepreneurial journey plan. We're actively exploring funding options and assessing the feasibility of launching the venture. Concurrently, we are also seeking potential partners to establish strategic collaborations.

In summary, attending the National I-Corps program not only unveiled the commercial potential of our innovation, but also set the foundation for future contributions to scientific domains. These contributions encompass helping new technologies be adopted faster in the best industry sectors, connecting research to real-world applications, and fostering collaborations across diverse disciplines to drive further advancements. 

 


Last Modified: 08/23/2023
Modified by: Kemper E Lewis
